children.value: Prepare to run Terraform to install the Development Tools into an existing IBM Cloud managed cluster

The IBM Garage for Cloud Developer Tools facilitate development and deployment of cloud-native applications. 
They can be hosted in any Kubernetes or OpenShift cluster, including those managed by the IBM Cloud.
In IBM Cloud, the cluster is hosted by either the
Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud

. 
These instructions assume that the cluster has already been created and explain 
how to configure and run the Terraform infrastructure-as-code (IasC) scripts to install the Developer Tools into that existing cluster.

: The Terraform scripts will clean up the cluster to remove any existing resources that overlap with the resources
provisioned by the scripts. You will need to remember to remove any IBM Cloud services that were previously
created.

to help automate the deletion You can also run it
to remove all the services beside

An IBM Cloud account with the ability to provision cloud service instances in the same region and zone as the existing cluster

Git repository to your local filesystem
Configure the key the CLI uses to create cloud services

The installation scripts need an API key to authenticate to IBM Cloud.
The following steps create the required API key and put them into a properties file.

cluster_exists="true"

Run the following command to run the Docker container:

This will install the Cloud Garage Tools Docker image and exec shell into the running container. The container will
 mount the filesystem's

. Once the Docker container has started and
 the script has exec shelled into it, you will see an IBM Garage banner. This will help you identify you are running

see the following guide link below.

The supplied Terraform script is ready to run using the settings in the properties files.
  You optionally can extend or modify the scripts and tailor them for your project's specific needs.
Note: If you run this approach multiple times remember to delete any pre existing cloud services that were created previously
Run this script in the container:
This script will create the Developer Tools environment.
The script will verify some basic settings and prompt if you want to proceed. After you select

(for yes),
  the Terraform Apply process will begin to create the infrastructure and services for your environment.
Installing the tools into an existing cluster takes about 30 minutes.

You should now have your Developer Tools environment
      fully provisioned and configured. Enjoy!
Once the Terraform scripts have finished, you can see the resources that the scripts created in IBM Cloud:

}; const Tabs = makeShortcode("Tabs"); const Tab = makeShortcode("Tab"); const PageDescription = makeShortcode("PageDescription"); const InlineNotification = makeShortcode("InlineNotification"); const AnchorLinks = makeShortcode("AnchorLinks"); const AnchorLink = makeShortcode("AnchorLink"); const layoutProps = { _frontmatter }; const MDXLayout = DefaultLayout export default function MDXContent({ components, ...props }) { return

{`Prepare to run Terraform to install the Development Tools into an existing IBM Cloud managed cluster`}

{`The IBM Garage for Cloud Developer Tools facilitate development and deployment of cloud-native applications. They can be hosted in any Kubernetes or OpenShift cluster, including those managed by the IBM Cloud.`}

{`In IBM Cloud, the cluster is hosted by either the `}{`IBM Cloud Kubernetes Service`}{` or `}{`Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud`}{`. These instructions assume that the cluster has already been created and explain how to configure and run the Terraform infrastructure-as-code (IasC) scripts to install the Developer Tools into that existing cluster.`}

{`Note`}{`: The Terraform scripts will clean up the cluster to remove any existing resources that overlap with the resources provisioned by the scripts. You will need to remember to remove any IBM Cloud services that were previously created.`}

{`Use the helper script `}{`terraform/scripts/destroy-service.sh`}{` to help automate the deletion You can also run it to remove all the services beside `}{`PostgreSQL`}{` `}{`./destroy-services.sh postgres`}

{`The following prerequisites are required before following the setup instructions:`}

  • {`An IBM Cloud account with the ability to provision cloud service instances in the same region and zone as the existing cluster`}

  • {`Install the `}{`Prerequisites`}{` listed before continuing`}

{`Obtain the Terraform infrastructure-as-code (IasC) scripts that will install the tools into your IBM Cloud managed cluster`}

  • {`Clone the `}{`ibm-garage-iteration-zero`}{` Git repository to your local filesystem`}

    {`git clone git@github.com:ibm-garage-cloud/ibm-garage-iteration-zero.git
`}

  • {`Switch to the cloned directory`}

    {`cd ibm-garage-iteration-zero
`}

{`Configure the key the CLI uses to create cloud services`}

  • {`The installation scripts need an API key to authenticate to IBM Cloud. The following steps create the required API key and put them into a properties file.`}

  • {`The `}{`credentials.properties`}{` property file:`}

    {`classic.username=
classic.api.key=
ibmcloud.api.key=
`}

  • {`Since the cluster already exists, well only need to set the `}{`ibmcloud.api.key`}{` property.`}

{`Step A. Create the credentials.properties file`}

  • {`Inside the `}{`iteration-zero-ibmcloud`}{` folder, copy `}{`credentials.template`}{` to a file named `}{`credentials.properties`}{`.`}

    {`cd iteration-zero-ibmcloud
cp credentials.template credentials.properties
`}

  • {`The `}{`credentials.properties`}{` file is already listed in the `}{`.gitignore`}{` file so that the file containing your private API key will not be pushed to the server repository.`}

{`Step B. Set the IBM Cloud API key`}

  • {`Follow these instructions to create an IBM Cloud API key:`}

    • {`Managing user API keys`}

  • {`Edit the `}{`credentials.properties`}{` file to set the value for the `}{`ibmcloud.api.key`}{` property.`}

{`Configure the properties describing the environment`}

{`The settings for installing the Developer Tools go in a single property file in the `}{`./terraform/settings`}{` directory:`}

  • {`environment.tfvars`}{` Properties for installing the Developer Tools`}

{`Follow the instructions below to set the existing clusters details in the `}{`environment.tfvars`}{` file.`}

{`Environment variables`}

{`The `}{`environment.tfvars`}{` properties will be used to install the Development Tools.`}

  • {`Typical values look like this:`}

    {`# The type of cluster that will be created/used (kubernetes or openshift)
cluster_type="kubernetes"
# Flag indicating if we are using an existing cluster or creating a new one
cluster_exists="true"

# The cluster name can be provided (particularly if using existing cluster) or it will
# default to '\${resource_group_name}-cluster'
cluster_name="catalyst-team-cluster"

resource_group_name="catalyst-team"
`}

  • {`Set them based on the existing cluster:`}

    • {`resource_group_name`}{` The existing clusters resource group`}
    • {`cluster_name`}{` The existing clusters name`}
    • {`cluster_exists`}{` Set to `}{`"true"`}{` for the existing cluster`}
    • {`cluster_type`}{` Specify whether the existing cluster is `}{`kubernetes`}{` or `}{`openshift`}
    • {`postgres_server_exists`}{` Specify whether the existing cluster already has an existing PostgreSQL service instance`}

{`Note:`}{` The values for `}{`resource_group_name`}{` and `}{`cluster_name`}{` can be found on the Resource List page in the IBM Cloud Console - `}{`https://cloud.ibm.com/resources`}

{` `}{` `}{` `}

{`Note: `}{`PostgreSQL`}{` can take some time to provision, so in some cases it is worth manually creating an instance. It needs to be in the same region and names `}{`-postgresql`}{`.`}

{`Run the scripts that create the environment`}

{`Having configured the `}{`credentials.properties`}{`, `}{`environment.tfvars`}{`, and `}{`vlan.tfvars`}{` properties files, we are now ready to kick off the installation.`}

{`Launch a `}{`Developer Tools Docker container`}{`.`}

  • {`Run the following command to run the Docker container:`}

    {`./launch.sh
`}

  • {`This will install the Cloud Garage Tools Docker image and exec shell into the running container. The container will mount the filesystems `}{`./terraform/`}{` directory as `}{`/home/devops/src/`}{`. Once the Docker container has started and the script has exec shelled into it, you will see an IBM Garage banner. This will help you identify you are running inside the Docker image that has just mounted your file system.`}

    {` For more information on the `}{`Developer Tools Image`}{` see the following guide link below.`}

  • {`Create the Developer Tools environment`}

    {` The supplied Terraform script is ready to run using the settings in the properties files. You optionally can extend or modify the scripts and tailor them for your projects specific needs.`}

{`Note: If you run this approach multiple times remember to delete any pre existing cloud services that were created previously`}

  • {`Run this script in the container:`}

    {`./runTerraform.sh
`}

    {` This script will create the Developer Tools environment.`}

    {` The script will verify some basic settings and prompt if you want to proceed. After you select `}{`Y`}{` (for yes), the Terraform Apply process will begin to create the infrastructure and services for your environment.`}

    {` Installing the tools into an existing cluster takes about 30 minutes.`}

    {` You should now have your Developer Tools environment fully provisioned and configured. Enjoy!`}

{`Developer Tools environment`}

{`Once the Terraform scripts have finished, you can see the resources that the scripts created in IBM Cloud:`}

  • {`In the IBM Cloud console, open the `}{`Resource List`}
  • {`On the Resource List page, filter by your Resource Group (e.g. `}{`catalyst-team`}{`)`}
  • {`You should see these resources listed:`}
    • {`Clusters`}{`: 1, either Kubernetes or OpenShift`}
    • {`Services`}{`: 5 or so, such as PostgreSQL, LogDNA, etc.`}
    • {`Storage`}{`: 1, an instance of Cloud Object Storage`}
  • {`Select the cluster and open the Kubernetes dashboard or OpenShift web console. You should see:`}
    • {`Namespaces: `}{`tools`}{`, `}{`dev`}{`, `}{`test`}{`, and `}{`staging`}
    • {`Deployments in the `}{`tools`}{` namespace: `}{`catalyst-dashboard`}{`, `}{`jenkins`}{`, etc.`}

{`To get started with code use the following guides:`}

Deploy First App Guides Developer Tools Image

{`Possible issues`}

{`If you find that that the Terraform provisioning has failed, try re-running the `}{`runTerraform.sh`}{` script again. The state will be saved and Terraform will try and apply the configuration to match the desired end state.`}

{`If you find that some of the services have failed to create in the time allocated, you can try this:`}

  • {`Manually delete the service instances in your resource group`}
  • {`Delete the `}{`workspace`}{` directory (which will remove any state that has been created by Terraform)`}
  • {`Re-run the `}{`runTerraform.sh`}{` script`}
    {`rm -rf workspace
./runTerraform.sh
`}
 ; } ; MDXContent.isMDXComponent = true;
